awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase I (Site Addition):  Expansion of CICI to Add a New Site at UTA on Sustainable Utilization of Composites in Infrastructure Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) is joining as a new site (CICI-UTA) to the existing ?Center for Integration of Composites into Infrastructure (CICI)?, a NSF Industry - University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) based in West Virginia University. The mission of CICI is to accelerate the adoption of composites into infrastructure applications with a particular focus on structural applications. CICI-UTA research team participation will enhance the integration of composite material utilization in various geo infrastructures areas including deep foundations (fender piles), mechanically stabilized earth walls (retaining walls), sheet piles, and others in both natural and extreme soil environments.  CICI-UTA will also work with all center sites in studying and implementing composites underground under harsh environment; harvesting composite samples for fundamental durability studies; and studying fibre-reinforced polymer composites as reinforcements in expansive soils to mitigate heaving failures. CICI-UTA will have strong educational and graduate training programs, and will train skilled and high caliber doctoral and masters students in civil engineering with special emphasis on composites. As a part of new Hispanic Serving Institute (HSI), UTA team members will be able to recruit Hispanic and other minority undergraduate and graduate students to involve and train them in the proposed research works. Research team will work with CICI sites to disseminate research results through conference presentations, publications in technical journals, short-courses and other means. Also, research results will be further integrated into the design, codes of practice, and academic curricula as desired by the industry/end-users. 

CICI-UTA will complement CICI?s research efforts by focusing and studying on different types of polymeric based geosynthetics and geocomposites, biopolymers and geopolymers and their applications in civil and military infrastructure in geotechnical, soil-structure and superstructure related areas. CICI-UTA team will also focus on bringing out sustainability aspects of using polymeric and other composites by addressing life cycle cost benefits. Research topics will be formulated, screened and selected by the Industrial Advisory Board members.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The CICI Phase I grant work started in 2015 and completed recently. As a part of this Phase I work, the research teams led by Dr. Anand Puppala at both the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA, before 2019) and then at Texas A and M University (TAMU, after 2019 to current) have completed several research studies. The team followed NSF IUCRC guidelines including the use of Life forms during industry board meetings and worked with Industry Advisory Board (IAB) in developing research projects that have high value for potential field implementation towards prolonging the life of civil infrastructure.

Over the last six-plus years, the research team led by Dr. Anand Puppala of TAMU (PI) conducted laboratory and full-scale tests on composites and demonstrated that they would complement the current CICI research efforts at West Virginia University, North Carolina State University, and University of Miami to study and use geocomposites in infrastructure applications. It should be mentioned that this CICI site at TAMU and formerly at UTA also studied and continue to provide research focus on life-cycle cost analysis and sustainability evaluation studies for a better understanding of the benefits of using novel composite materials when applied to a wide variety of civil infrastructure projects comprising of structures such as dams, embankments, and walls; transportation infrastructure such as pavements, runways, bridges, and others and building and other industrial infrastructure. All these applications need to carry out both fundamental research with a focus on material science and development, and applied research including infrastructure instrumentation and monitoring, field implementation and evaluation, and others.

Specific areas of research topics executed by the CICI team led by Puppala included, but are not limited to: (1) Utilization of polymer-based Geosynthetics including Geotextiles and Geocells in pavement layer systems; (2) Use of Polymeric fibers to reinforce soils of geocomposite systems; (3) Use of Expanded Polystyrene (EPS) products in bridge embankment support layer systems; (4) Application of fibers in different construction materials to enhance their engineering strength and ductility and resistance to cracks; (5) Use of Geofoams for thermal encapsulation of foundations; (6) Use of wicking geotextiles for stabilization of expansive soils; (7) Use of Geocells to support pavement infrastructure and (8) Address sustainability and resiliency aspects on the use of polymeric to non-polymeric composites in infrastructural elements.

Researchers have been working on many geotechnical applications and the majority of the industry funding was in the Geotechnical Engineering area. These funding supports are used to perform research related to the use of geosynthetic materials to chemical additives to stabilize problematic soils comprising of soft soils, expansive soils and others; address sustainability-resiliency enhancements in the use of the novel and innovative products; develop and study ultra-high performance fiber-reinforced concrete materials with compressive strengths and others. Such materials will not only enhance design service life but will also provide resistance to extreme loading caused by wetting and drying, impact, blast, freeze-thaw, and earthquakes. During the Phase I studies, the CICI research team lead by Dr. Puppala published more than 15 journal papers with several under review, presented 16+ conference papers, and submitted 1 patent application. The CICI UTA site has been supporting 3 Post-docs (2 current), 8 PhD students (6 graduated), 3 MS students (all 3 graduated), and 6 undergraduate students. Some of the papers have received national awards of significance and for example, Dr. Puppala and his research team have received two best papers of the sessions from two of the Transportation Research Board (TRB) Design and Construction sections. Some of the papers were nominated for ASCE GeoInstitute paper awards. Many of the doctoral and master's students involved in Center research are either working in industries linked to civil engineering infrastructure fields or accepted postdoctoral fellowships in academic settings. Three of the postdoctoral fellows trained by this center have received tenure track faculty appointments in the USA and hence it can be mentioned that CICI site at TAMU has been valuable in creating skilled student workforce. . 

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2021
Modified by: Anand J Puppala
